Pendara
Full Stack Developer
April 2017 - Jun 2018

Job Description

Full Stack developer in couple of projects. First one (AutoApp) was an online service for requesting car health. I was PHP (Laravel), Node.js and ReactJS developer on that project. The second project was a social networking project named Wikievent, which I was PHP (Laravel and Codeigniter) developer on that project. I also was the SQL writer in all projects. I was the Pendara’s CEO consultant in technical decisions.


Technologies

PHP (Laravel - Codeigniter) , Node.js, ReactJS, TypeScript, SQL and MySQL, Redis, Restful API System, Clouding (Server), SCRUM Methodology, Git Version Control


Important things i’ve done at Pendara

I was the head of designing Wikievent project’s database (MySQL). I performed the migration from Codeigniter framework to Laravel in Wikievent project. I also proposed the migration from VPS to Clouding (based on Docker system) because of it’s advantages, which was approved by Pendara’s CEO. I proposed perform Application Testing and Documenting to make the development path more reliable and make the project more scale able which was approved by Pendara’s CEO. In AutoApp project I proposed the Long Polling System instead of WebSocket which reduced the pressure on server. I also found the formula for getting the nearby cars on the map by trigonometric calculations.

»Usage

Using it is pretty straight forward. Create several(as much as you need) divs or «section» elements each with it's unique id to hold your content. Make sure to have an error section (id="error") with some information to warn the user when he/she mistypes a command or if there is no section with that name, think of it as a 404 page.

A section with id="help" is also required so you can list all the available sections and let your users know what words to write to access that particular content.

The input field must be a standalone element and must not be placed inside any of the content divs or sections, and make sure you give it a classname "command", if you want to name it anything else you need to edit the app.js and change all instances of .command in the script to match your chosen classname.

In short, just view the source code of this demo, copy/modify it to your liking making sure you include the error and help sections.
